prior_works.title: Cluster Ensembles — A Knowledge Reuse Framework for Combining Multiple Partitions
prior_works.role: Consensus/ensemble clustering and label-agreement measurement across partitions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC’s cluster-label matching (CLM) to pick a benchmark view operationalizes the cluster-ensemble idea of selecting/assessing partitions via inter-partition agreement, using label correspondences to quantify which view best represents the others.

prior_works.title: The Hungarian Method for the Assignment Problem
prior_works.role: Foundational algorithm for optimal label matching via linear assignment
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC’s CLM hinges on optimally matching cluster labels between views, a direct application of the Hungarian assignment formulation to compute maximal label alignment across clusterings.

prior_works.title: Co-regularized Multi-view Spectral Clustering
prior_works.role: Multi-view clustering via cross-view agreement of latent cluster indicators
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC is motivated by and departs from this consensus-view paradigm: rather than assuming perfectly synchronized samples for co-regularization, it first aligns unsynchronized views and then enforces structure similarity to realize cross-view agreement.

prior_works.title: Manifold Alignment without Correspondence
prior_works.role: Unsupervised alignment across data sets using intrinsic structure without known point correspondences
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC adopts the same core principle—align views via structural similarity instead of explicit one-to-one correspondences—by constructing a cross-view similarity graph that uses within-view geometry to drive sample alignment.

prior_works.title: Spectral Grouping Using the Nyström Method
prior_works.authors: Charless Fowlkes, Serge Belongie, Fan Chung, Jitendra Malik
prior_works.role: Scalable spectral methods via representing points by similarities to a subset (landmarks/columns)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC’s representation of non-aligned samples via similarities to aligned samples echoes Nyström/landmark ideas to reduce complexity, enabling scalable construction of cross-view similarity graphs.

prior_works.title: A Spectral Technique for Correspondence Problems Using Pairwise Constraints
prior_works.role: Graph-based matching using affinity structure for unsupervised correspondence
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SSA-MVC’s alignment criterion—building a similarity graph between samples across views and inferring correspondences—draws on spectral correspondence principles that leverage pairwise structural affinities to guide matching.

prior_works.title: Global alignment of multiple protein interaction networks with application to functional orthology detection (IsoRank)
prior_works.authors: Rohit Singh, Jinbo Xu, Bonnie Berger
prior_works.role: Network alignment via similarity propagation over product graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By using inter-sample similarity structure to align entities across graphs/views, SSA-MVC parallels IsoRank’s idea that cross-graph alignment should be driven by neighborhood-structure similarity rather than raw feature matching.

synthesis_narrative:
SSA-MVC addresses the overlooked but realistic setting where multi-view samples are unsynchronized across views. Its pipeline—choosing a benchmark view by label agreement, representing non-aligned samples via similarities to aligned ones, and constructing a cross-view similarity graph to drive alignment—sits at the intersection of ensemble clustering, unsupervised alignment, and scalable spectral approximation.
The benchmark selection via cluster-label matching is rooted in cluster ensemble principles (Strehl & Ghosh), which quantify agreement across partitions, and is operationalized with optimal label correspondence using the Hungarian assignment (Kuhn). Rather than presuming synchronized instances for co-regularization as in co-regularized multi-view spectral clustering (Kumar & Daumé), SSA-MVC first reconciles unsynchronized data, thereby extending cross-view agreement to settings without one-to-one sample pairing.
Its core alignment criterion is structurally inspired: like manifold alignment without correspondence (Wang & Mahadevan), SSA-MVC leverages within-view geometry to infer cross-view correspondences, and akin to spectral/graph matching methods (Leordeanu & Hebert) and IsoRank, it promotes matches whose neighborhoods are mutually consistent across views. Finally, scalability is achieved by representing non-aligned samples through similarities to already aligned samples—conceptually analogous to Nyström/landmark-based spectral methods (Fowlkes et al.) that compress pairwise structures via anchor relations. Together, these ideas directly inform SSA-MVC’s scalable cross-view sample alignment with view-structure similarity, enabling robust multi-view clustering under unsynchronized sampling.
